sections.heading: SECTION 1 ‚Äî PURPOSE OF MULTI-MEASURE STACKING
sections.content:
1.1 Purpose This manual defines the engineering and financial logic necessary to combine multiple energy efficiency measures (EEMs) ‚Äî including lighting, HVAC, battery storage, EV charging, building controls, and demand response ‚Äî into a unified modeling framework.

The goal is to allow AI to: Combine measures without double-counting savings Respect interactive effects between systems Determine stacking priority Find optimal bundles Calculate combined economics Identify conflicts Explain interactions clearly Avoid infeasible combinations

1.2 Measures Considered This manual covers:

Lighting retrofits Lighting controls HVAC controls VAV/VVT/CAV optimization RTU retrofits Chiller + boiler upgrades Battery storage (peak shaving, arbitrage, DR) EV charging infrastructure Demand response programs Building automation system upgrades Retrocommissioning

1.3 AI Responsibilities AI must: Identify compatible measure combinations Reject incompatible combinations Apply correct modeling order Apply interaction factors Avoid double counting Model combined economics Adjust measure savings when interacting Provide clear measure-level and total savings breakdown Flag measures that become unnecessary due to others

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 2 ‚Äî MULTI-MEASURE INTERACTION PRINCIPLES
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

2.1 Why Measures Interact Energy measures interact because:

Lighting reduces cooling load Lighting increases heating load HVAC resets reduce fan + compressor energy HVAC commissioning affects cooling loads Battery reduces peak but does not reduce actual kWh EV load increases peak and kWh DR participation affects battery availability Controls flatten profiles Boiler reset interacts with VAV reheat CHW reset interacts with economizers

2.2 Measure Interaction Types Type A ‚Äî Synergistic (1+1 > 2) Example: CHW reset + SAT reset + static pressure reset These produce compound savings.

Type B ‚Äî Overlapping (1+1 < 2) Example: Lighting + SAT reset, where lighting reduces cooling load, shrinking SAT reset savings.

Type C ‚Äî Conflicting Example: HVAC load reduction needed for DR while SAT reset also active; some combinations reduce effective savings.

Type D ‚Äî Independent (1+1 = sum) Example: Exterior lighting + chiller optimization.

AI must classify interactions among all measures.

2.3 Interaction Effects on Savings Total savings must follow:

TotalSavings = Sum(Savings_i) ‚àí OverlapLosses

sections.heading: SynergyGains
sections.content:
2.4 Interaction Priority Interactive effects must be applied in hierarchical order:

Lighting ‚Üí HVAC ‚Üí Controls ‚Üí Battery ‚Üí DR ‚Üí EV

Reason: Lighting affects HVAC HVAC affects controls Controls affect battery operation Battery affects DR EV affects tariff and DR

AI must use this exact chain.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 3 ‚Äî MEASURE ORDER OF OPERATIONS
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

3.1 Why Order Matters Incorrect measure ordering leads to double counting or misallocation of savings. AI must always stack measures in a deterministic sequence.

3.2 Order of Operations Correct order is:

Step 1 ‚Äî Compute baseline loads Step 2 ‚Äî Apply lighting retrofit Step 3 ‚Äî Apply lighting controls Step 4 ‚Äî Apply HVAC optimization Step 5 ‚Äî Apply HVAC equipment upgrades Step 6 ‚Äî Apply battery modeling (shaving + arbitrage + DR interaction) Step 7 ‚Äî Apply EV charging load Step 8 ‚Äî Apply DR program modeling Step 9 ‚Äî Recalculate tariff (including rate migration) Step 10 ‚Äî Compute combined savings Step 11 ‚Äî Apply incentive stacking Step 12 ‚Äî Compute total financial metrics Step 13 ‚Äî Validate

AI must never deviate from this order.

3.3 Why This Order Works Lighting modifies HVAC loads HVAC modifies comfort + reheat Controls modify HVAC behavior Battery modifies electricity bill but not HVAC loads EV modifies demand and TOU costs DR interacts with battery and HVAC Tariff migration depends on aggregated results

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 4 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN LIGHTING AND HVAC
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

4.1 Lighting ‚Üí HVAC Interaction Lighting reduction lowers cooling demand and increases heating demand.

CoolingInteractionSavings = Lighting_kWh_reduction √ó CoolingFraction / HVAC_EER_equivalent

HeatingInteractionPenalty = Lighting_kWh_reduction √ó HeatingFraction / BoilerEfficiency

AI must compute these interaction effects.

4.2 How Lighting Affects HVAC Savings Lighting reduces: Reheat Cooling load Supply air temperature reset potential

Lighting affects HVAC measures: SAT reset CHW reset Economizer operation Static pressure reset Reheat reset

AI must shrink HVAC savings accordingly.

4.3 Interaction Ranges Cooling-dominant climates ‚Üí strong interaction (10‚Äì20% savings tied to lighting load) Heating-dominant climates ‚Üí small or negative interaction Mild climates ‚Üí moderate interaction

4.4 Validation If combined lighting + HVAC savings > 50% of total building load ‚Üí unrealistic, flag.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 5 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN HVAC MEASURES
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

5.1 HVAC Measure Synergies HVAC measures often reinforce each other:

Static pressure reset ‚Üí lowers fan energy SAT reset ‚Üí reduces cooling + reheat CHW reset ‚Üí improves chiller efficiency Boiler reset ‚Üí reduces heating therms Economizer ‚Üí reduces compressor kWh

5.2 Synergistic Savings Example If SAT reset and static pressure reset applied: FanSavings_spreset = cubic CoolingSavings_satreset = linear CombinedSavings = synergy factor applied AI must apply synergy factor ~1.05‚Äì1.15

5.3 Overlaps Few HVAC measures overlap: SAT reset reduces cooling, which limits CHW reset effect Static pressure reset reduces airflow, limiting SAT reset savings Boiler reset reduces reheat availability

AI must subtract overlap.

5.4 HVAC + Controls Measures Controls such as DCV reduce HVAC runtime, impacting CHW reset savings, SAT reset savings, and reheat savings.

AI must avoid double counting.

5.5 Validation If HVAC stack savings > 30% of building consumption ‚Üí likely unrealistic unless poor baseline controls.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 6 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN HVAC AND BATTERY
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

6.1 Battery ‚Üí HVAC Battery storage affects electricity cost profile, not HVAC kWh consumption.

AI must NOT apply HVAC load reduction due to battery.

6.2 HVAC ‚Üí Battery HVAC schedules heavily influence peak demand. Peak shaving must consider HVAC-driven peaks.

6.3 Interaction Logic If HVAC reduces peak demand significantly ‚Üí battery peak shaving potential decreases.

BatteryPeakShave_new = min(Battery_kW, Peak_new ‚àí TargetPeak)

AI must adopt the new reduced baseline peak for battery modeling.

6.4 HVAC ‚Üí DR HVAC can provide DR load shedding. Battery+HVAC DR synergy possible.

AI must model coordinated dispatch during DR.

6.5 Validation AI must ensure: HVAC savings do not reduce kWh eligible for battery arbitrage Battery DR does not create HVAC comfort issues

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 7 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN BATTERY AND EV LOAD
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

7.1 Battery ‚Üí EV Battery can mitigate EV demand impact. Battery may reduce: EV demand charges Transformer overload Peak impact

AI must calculate battery-based peak shaving on EV loads separately.

7.2 EV ‚Üí Battery EV charging increases site peak ‚Üí increases battery dispatch demand.

Battery must have enough: Power (kW) Energy (kWh) SOC reserves

7.3 Combined Load Modeling EV_peak_new = EVPeak_before_batt ‚àí min(Batt_kW, EVPeak_before_batt)

Battery delivers: kWh_EV_support = min(Batt_kWh, EV_kWh_needed_for_peak)

7.4 Validation If EV load exceeds battery rating by >3√ó ‚Üí battery insufficient as mitigation.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 8 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN DR AND BATTERY
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

8.1 DR ‚Üí Battery DR event reserves must be prioritized over arbitrage.

Battery must start at sufficient SOC pre-event:

SOC_required = (Committed_kW √ó EventDuration) / E_usable

8.2 Battery ‚Üí DR Battery may supply full DR curtailment if appropriately sized.

AI must check: Battery_kW ‚â• committed_kW Battery_kWh ‚â• committed_kW √ó event_duration

8.3 Interaction Constraints Battery DR reduces arbitrage cycles. Battery DR may reduce available peak shaving.

AI must update savings accordingly.

8.4 Validation If battery used for DR, arbitrage savings must be reduced in modeling.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 9 ‚Äî CROSS-MEASURE OPTIMIZATION LOGIC
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

9.1 Purpose AI must evaluate all measures together to form an optimal package.

9.2 Multi-Measure Objective Choose measure bundle that maximizes: Net present value Payback IRR Demand reduction Carbon reduction Customer-specified goals

9.3 Optimization Process For each measure i: Compute standalone savings Compute interactions with all previous measures Apply incentives Apply stacking rules Compute financial metrics

AI must iterate through all valid combinations.

9.4 Dominance Rule Measure A dominates measure B when: A has higher NPV A meets constraints B meets A has lower CAPEX A offers larger savings

AI must eliminate dominated measures.

9.5 Multi-Measure Feasibility AI must drop measures that: Offer small marginal savings Are redundant after previous optimizations Conflict with customer goals Exceed budget or panel capacity

END OF PART 1

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 10 ‚Äî FULL MULTI-MEASURE STACKING FORMULAS
sections.content:
10.1 Purpose of Stacking Formulas Stacking formulas ensure all measures are evaluated in correct sequence and that savings are neither understated nor overstated.

10.2 General Stacking Formula TotalSavings = Œ£(BaseSavings_i √ó AdjustmentFactor_i) ‚àí OverlapLosses

sections.heading: Where:
sections.content:
BaseSavings_i = savings of measure i if applied alone AdjustmentFactor_i = factor adjustment after previous measures OverlapLosses = reductions due to overlapping effects SynergyGains = additional gains from measure interaction

10.3 Example Adjustment Factors Lighting retrofit reduces cooling load ‚Üí reduces HVAC cooling savings. AdjustmentFactor_HVAC = 1 ‚àí CoolingInteractionFraction

If lighting reduces cooling by 15%: AdjustmentFactor_HVAC ‚âà 0.85

10.4 Overlap Losses Overlap occurs when two measures target the same energy stream.

Examples: SAT reset and CHW reset overlap on cooling DCV and economizer overlap on ventilation air HVAC DR and HVAC optimization overlap on airflow

OverlapLoss = min(Savings_A, Savings_B) √ó OverlapCoefficient

10.5 Synergy Gains Certain measures increase the effectiveness of other measures.

Examples: VFD + Static Pressure Reset SAT reset + Chilled Water Reset Battery + DR

SynergyGain = Savings_A √ó Savings_B √ó SynergyCoefficient

Typical SynergyCoefficient = 0.05‚Äì0.20

10.6 HVAC-Lighting Interaction Formula HVAC_Interaction_AdjustedSavings = LightingSavings √ó InteractionFactor(CZ, building_type)

Where InteractionFactor is based on climate zone.

10.7 Battery + HVAC Integration Formula BatteryPeakShave_afterHVAC = min(Battery_kW, Peak_afterHVAC ‚àí TargetPeak)

Battery savings recalculated after HVAC measures applied.

10.8 EV + Battery Integration Formula Battery supports EV loads: EVPeakReduced = EVPeak ‚àí min(Batt_kW, EVPeak)

AI must re-evaluate EV-augmented peak.

10.9 DR + Battery Integration Formula Battery DR energy: DR_EnergyRequired = Committed_kW √ó EventDuration

Battery must supply this before arbitrage is re-modeled.

ArbitrageReduction = (min(DR_EnergyRequired, ArbitrageEnergy)) √ó Spread

------------------------------------------------------------

Baseline: Lighting: 250,000 kWh/yr HVAC Cooling: 450,000 kWh/yr Heating: 25,000 therms/yr Peak: 350 kW

Measures: Lighting retrofit (LED) Lighting controls HVAC static pressure reset CHW reset Boiler reset Battery (100 kW / 400 kWh)

11.2 Example 2 ‚Äî Hospital (CHW plant + Steam + Lighting + DR + Battery)

Complex interactions: Lighting reduces cooling ‚Üí reduces chiller load HVAC resets reduce heating ‚Üí reduce steam demand Battery DR must reserve SOC, reducing arbitrage DR stacked with HVAC resets Battery DR + hospital peaks overlapping

11.3 Example 3 ‚Äî School (RTUs + Boiler + Lighting + Controls) Lighting retrofit reduces RTU cooling HVAC resets smaller because RTUs are packaged DX Boiler heating penalty moderate Demand reduction from RTU staging improves battery value

AI must stack: Lighting Controls RTU advanced logic Battery

sections.heading: SECTION 12 ‚Äî MULTI-MEASURE VALIDATION MATRIX
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

12.1 Purpose Ensures multi-measure models avoid double counting, incorrect stacking, or impossible combinations.

12.2 Validation Test Cases

Test 1 ‚Äî Lighting + HVAC If lighting + HVAC savings > 50% total consumption ‚Üí fail unless HID-heavy facility.

Test 2 ‚Äî HVAC + Battery If HVAC and battery both reduce peak for the same interval ‚Üí allow only ONE savings source.

Test 3 ‚Äî DR + Battery If DR reduces peak and battery also reduces the same peak ‚Üí apply DR first, battery second or vice versa depending on goal. Avoid double counting.

Test 4 ‚Äî EV + Battery If battery reduces EV peak, EV must not count DR reduction separately unless EV curtailment occurs.

Test 5 ‚Äî Battery DR + Arbitrage If battery used for DR, arbitrage reduced proportionally. Failure to reduce ‚Üí fail.

Test 6 ‚Äî Boiler Reset + Lighting If boiler reset savings > heating load after lighting retrofit ‚Üí fail.

Test 7 ‚Äî Controls + HVAC If combined controls + HVAC savings exceed thermodynamic limits ‚Üí fail.

Test 8 ‚Äî Tariff Migration If tariff switch triggered by HVAC + lighting + battery combination ‚Üí must rebuild entire bill. If not ‚Üí fail.

Test 9 ‚Äî Incentive Stacking If incentive stacking > 100% of CAPEX ‚Üí fail.

Test 10 ‚Äî Comfort or Safety If combination violates HVAC standards ‚Üí reject.

12.3 AI Response to Failures Reject combined measure Flag failure Recommend revised combination Ask for missing data Enforce conservative assumptions

sections.heading: SECTION 13 ‚Äî COMPLETE MULTI-MEASURE OPTIMIZATION ENGINE LOGIC
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

13.1 Objective Find the measure bundle that maximizes user goal (e.g., ROI, NPV, DR revenue, demand reduction).

13.2 Optimization Algorithm

Step 1 ‚Äî Identify all feasible measures based on system type Step 2 ‚Äî Calculate standalone savings Step 3 ‚Äî Apply stacking order Step 4 ‚Äî Recalculate loads Step 5 ‚Äî Apply battery modeling Step 6 ‚Äî Apply DR modeling Step 7 ‚Äî Apply EV loads Step 8 ‚Äî Apply tariff migration Step 9 ‚Äî Compute incentive stacking Step 10 ‚Äî Compute final savings and financial metrics Step 11 ‚Äî Check all validation rules Step 12 ‚Äî Produce sorted bundle recommendations

13.3 Dominance Pruning Remove measure bundles that: Underperform across all metrics Violate constraints Cost more and save less

13.4 Customer-Goal-Based Prioritization If user prioritizes: Demand Reduction ‚Üí HVAC + battery prioritized DR Revenue ‚Üí Battery + HVAC DR Energy Savings ‚Üí Lighting + HVAC optimization Carbon Reduction ‚Üí Lighting + HVAC + heat pump retrofits Capex Minimization ‚Üí Controls + lighting

13.5 Bundle Explanation AI must provide: What measures included Why included Why others excluded Savings breakdown Financial impacts Risks Uncertainties

sections.heading: SECTION 14 ‚Äî AI GUARDRAILS FOR MULTI-MEASURE STACKING
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

14.1 Core Rule AI must NOT double count savings under any circumstances.

14.2 Lighting Guardrails Lighting savings cannot fully compound with HVAC savings Lighting + controls must apply controls to post-retrofit load Exterior lighting savings do not impact HVAC

14.3 HVAC Guardrails HVAC savings cannot be added twice for overlapping measures HVAC comfort limits always enforced HVAC reset applicable only to VAV/CHW systems

14.4 Battery Guardrails Battery does not reduce HVAC consumption Battery does not reduce lighting consumption Battery savings only impact cost, not physical HVAC load Battery DR must reduce arbitrage savings

14.5 EV Guardrails EV peak cannot be reduced twice (battery + DR) unless distinct intervals EV diversity must remain realistic EV DR only eligible in fleet or controllable environments

14.6 DR Guardrails DR must never be double counted with peak shaving DR baseline must be validated DR revenue must match performance

14.7 Tariff Guardrails Tariff migration must be fully recomputed Seasonal TOU must be enforced Ratchet logic must be applied

14.8 Incentive Guardrails No overlapping incentives Correct stacking order Correct basis adjustment
